Comment: I have no fundamental problem with privatizing mail delivery. It's a service that private industry can easily supply, especially if the government were to create a common-carrier style framework where private carriers would be required to interface with each other and transfer parcels carrier to carrier with each receiving a pre-set share of the revenue. That way, the system could be operated by many competing firms that could each win contracts by being the lowest bidder, delivering a high quality service at the lowest possible prices for consumers. People in rural areas that have higher delivery costs, they might pay slightly higher rates than people in suburban and urban areas, but they would pay the lowest commercially viable rate for that service, and they save a lot of money on housing and food by living in the rural area in the first place.  But you know that's not how our government would do it, democrat or republican. There's no way they don't hand the whole or huge portions of the work to a single oligarch, creating a massive barrier to entry for possible competitors, leading to high prices in the long run when the operator claims they "have no choice but to raise prices", but there's no competitor out there to offer a better deal anyway. There's no way they don't subsidize the mail to rural areas using revenue from the denser areas.
